title: Enable Console to use Fallback Fonts to display emoji and more Unicode codepoints
body: It'd be nice if Console could support font fallback to enable it to display emoji, east-Asian glyphs, and Unicode symbols.

comments.body:
Yep, completely agree on this one.
Would also be helpful to provide fonts that fully match (including special characters and other languages) the default fonts of the Linux distributions that will be available in the Windows Store... So install Fedora, and get RedHat's default font... Install Ubuntu and get all of the Ubuntu Fonts...
It seems this website, doesn't support multibyte strings (4 bytes), my message was truncated when I tried to add some monkey emoji here

Emoji in the bash. (and maybe cmd). It is not really a priority, but it is always good for our mood to see a monkey or any other in our terminals. Currently, ubuntu supports colorless emoji in the bash, that is not so great but better than nothing, and macOS users have colorful emoji (that is the only thing I envy of them)

Yes, I'd like my zsh prompt to show this line containing Powerline characters correctly:
~/.oh-my-zsh   master 
That exakt line works in Notepad, either using the Inconsolata for Powerline font, or using the Inconsolata font after configuring font linking in the registry to user the Powerline font for unrecognized characters (in HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\FontLink\SystemLink)
